title: 112_s3531
content: Expansion of credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. The amendment increases the credit percentage for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property to 50 percent. There is no dollar limitation for property related to hydrogen. The credit is also allowable for refueling property for certain motor vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads, with a focus on hydrogen fuel storage or dispensing. The amendment expands the definition of specified off-highway vehicles for the hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit. It includes vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads propelled by motor, regardless of registration for highway use. The definition of specified off-highway vehicles for the hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit is expanded to include vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads propelled by motor, regardless of registration for highway use. Additionally, the credit for hydrogen property is extended through 2016. The credit for hydrogen property is extended through December 31, 2016. The effective date for the amendments applies to property placed in service after the enactment date for taxable years ending after that date. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells, with a 50% credit for qualified fuel cell property in a combined heat and power system with an energy efficiency of 70% or more, and a 40% credit for systems with an energy efficiency of at least 60% but less than 70%. The text chunk discusses amendments to the tax code related to energy efficiency percentages for qualified fuel cell property. Amendments include changes to section 48(a)(2)(A)(iii) and section 48(a)(2)(A) of the tax code. The maximum credit for qualified fuel cell property is also addressed in the amendment to section 48(c)(1) of the tax code. The maximum credit for qualified fuel cell property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to $2,500 for each 0.5 kilowatt of capacity for certain types of property. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
